In addition, I'd recommend not to make use of type=
 attributes because they lead to unintended coupling between representation=
s (or the code that produces these representations) and the set of used med=
ia types. Any time you remove or add support for a certain media type, you =
need to check and update all the code that produces corresponding 'type' at=
tributes. That's likely to be a maintenance nightmare.

HTTP (content negot=
iation) is designed to save us from such dependencies.

Here is the 'patter=
n':

Suppose the link <link href=3D"/docs/example-doc" />, you'd then do th=
is:


GET /docs/example-doc
Accept: text/html


200 Ok
Content-Type: text/h=
tml
Content-Location: /docs/example-doc.html
Vary: accept

<html>
...
</htm=

The Content-Location header tells the client all it needs to know regar=
ding the negotiation that took place. If the server wanted to inform the cl=
ient about any variants, it could add an Alternates[1] header:
